detailedRequirements:
The purpose of the task is create a simple POC that demonstrates how an analog pressure sensor connected to a microcontroller can push an event over a network and be consumed by another system through a service.  To demonstrate the consumption of the analog data through a sensor, this POC should use ubidots to create a dashboard to collect the data.  


- Submissions for this challenge should include:
- Documented code and code deployment procedures (how to push code to a physical device and simulator)
- Identifying simulator and documenting how to use the simulator
- Documentation of how the ubidots services were created and a link to the dashboard that is used to collect the data.
- A short video of how the application works in the simulator environment

Submissions for this challenge will be judged primarily on the video include don the submission as well as the quality of the code and documentation.  This challenge will use the Innovation Scorecard and will be evaluated subjectively.  We encourage the community to look for innovative ways to develop this POC and to demonstrate its functionality

Challenge Details

This link is to a diagram that shows the components that make up the POC to be delivered for this challenge

Analog Pressure Sensor (potentiometer)

- A sensor will be connected to a microcontroller. 
- A Potentiometer is an optional choice as its analog and the Arduino web site has a code sample for using this type of hardware.

Microcontroller selection options

The pressure sensitive button will be connected to a microcontroller.   Possible products include:

Arduino

- The arduino is probably the most supported microcontroller and has analog inputs (which we need for the pressure sensitive switch or button)
- There are simulators and emulators available online
- This is the recommended solution as it provides support for simulators.  It also has sample code for developing part of the solution.
- Samples
** Sample analog input functionality
** Sample HTTP request

Photon based Solution

- It does have the advantages of being wi-fi enabled out of the box plus analog GPIO pins.
- There isn’t a simulator for this solution.  however, the APIs are straightforward and cost is pretty low for a device. 
- Included with the photon cloud is an event listener (pub/sub) and webhooks

Raspberry Pi

- RPi may not be an ideal solution as it doesn’t support analog input 
- If RPi was necessary could approach using an ADC intermediary such as the MCP3008 but this is going to increase the complexity of the solution

Other

- You are welcome to use any off the shelf diy MCU that might be avaiable from sparkfun.com or adafruit.com

Event Publisher Service 

Custom code will be developed and deployed to the microcontroller that will receive the event from the sensor and push the event over a network to a an endpoint running on ubidots. 

ubidots Integration 

- Ubidots is a third party service that offers a platform for developers that enables them to easily capture sensor data and turn it into useful information.
- For this POC, create a ubidots account and configure it to collect data sent from the sensor and microcontroller.  This service will provide validation that data is being collected and pushed from the microcontroller correctly.
- Ubidots also includes a dashboard that can provide analytics on the data collected which is useful.
- Ubidots includes a free pricing option that will be sufficient for this POC.
- Link to tutorial on ubidots for configuring arduino to connect to ubidots. 
- You are free to create a time base chart or explore threshold alarm events in ubidots
